author: alyeska_97
content:
I had a question about ZK-STARKS - in this article Vitalik created: https://vitalik.ca/general/2017/11/09/starks_part_1.html, he talks about how it is tough to mock a polynomial P(x) of degree N, since any two polynomials of degree N will agree at most on N points. If the range of the domain verified is >> N, then it is not feasible to "recreate" a polynomial to satisfy a ZK-STARK.

However, one problem has been bugging me - the prover is the one who creates the merkel tree that contains the values of the polynomial (`P(x)`) and the multiplier of Z(x) to get P(x) (`D(x)`). Since the values of Z(x) are public knowledge, instead of trying to create a polynomial, couldn't a crafty prover create a merkle tree where each value of `P(x)` is equal to each value of `Z(x)` and `D(x)` is always equal to 1?
